This procedure is an ERCP with a sphincterotomy and stent placement. 'The major papilla was normal in appearance. 'The bile duct was deeply cannulated with a 0.035 inch guide wire. ' preloaded into the sphincterotome and the bile dilatory duct was dilated up to 15 mm with a sharp cut-off from a 3 cm leg and distal structure. 'The cystic duct partially opacified and appeared to be inserted just above the distal biliary structure. 'The intrahepatics were diffusely dilated. ' An 8 mm bleeder sphincterotomy was performed using an ERBE electrocautery. 'There was no bleeding following sphincterotomy. 'A wall flex 10 mm diameter into 60 mm long unrecovered CEMS was inserted over the guide wire across the distal bleeder structure. ' It was good contrast and bioflow. 'The duodenoscope was done completely, withdrawn from the patient, and the procedure was completed. 'There was a minimal acetaminophen blood loss, and no specimens were obtained. 'It's recommended to follow up with oncology and surgery. 'Do not anticipate. 'Don't think there'll be a repeat EUS or ERCP unless there's a biliary obstruction development.

'After some maneuvering, there was successful straightening of the wire. 'The wire was then advanced into distal pancreatic duct followed by the sphincterotome. 'Contrast injected which showed a dilated bile duct with distal narrowing and multiple filling defects consistent with pancreatic duct stones. 'The wire was exchanged and a pancreatic sphincterotomy was performed. 'Then dilated dilatation of the distal duct and major papilla was performed up to ' 6 mm using a hurricane balloon. 'An extraction balloon was then advanced over the wire and multiple balloon sweeps yielded multiple pancreatic stones. 'An occlusion pancreatogram showed improved pancreatic stone burden and drainage. 'A 7 French 12 cm pancreatic stent was then successfully deployed over the wire. ' A second wire was advanced along the wire and attempts to advance the five French were unsuccessful. 'Contrast drainage was excellent. 'There was a complex procedure. 'This was a complex procedure taking more than 70 minutes. 'And then the scope was completely withdrawn from the patient and the procedure was completed.

This procedure is an ERCP. 'The indication is for a 49-year-old male here for an ERCP for the treatment of pancreatic duct stones. 'The patient has a history of chronic calcific pancreatitis, secondary to alcohol abuse, related to recurrent acute pancreatitis and smoking, complicated by recurrent episodes of abdominal pain. 'CT abdomen in April 2023 showed diffuse pancreatic atrophy associated with multiple PD stones and a 3.5 into 2.9 centimeter pseudocyst. 'The patient is undergoing an ERCP for the treatment of these stones. ' After the risks, benefits, and alternatives of the procedure were thoroughly explained, informed consent was verified, confirmed, and timeout was successfully executed by the treatment team. 'With the patient in the left semi-prone position, medications were administered intravenously. 'The Olympus TJF Q190 duodenoscope was passed from the mouth into the esophagus, further advanced into the stomach, and then passed into the second portion of the duodenum. 'A scalp film was obtained prior to the insertion of the duodenoscope. ' and was unremarkable. 'The duodenal scope was passed into the descending duodenum without a detailed examination of the upper GI tract. 'The major papilla was examined and appeared unremarkable. 'Attempts were then made to cannulate the pancreatic duct using a tritome-syncterotome preloaded with a 0.025-inch guide wire. 'Selective cannulation of the pancreatic duct was achieved. 'However, attempts at deep cannulation were unsuccessful. 'Advancing the wire to the pancreatic duct in the body were unsuccessful as the wire was recurrently retained in the pancreatic duct in the head of ' or was redirected into the uncinated branch. 'After multiple unsuccessful attempts, repeat attempts were made using an angle-tipped 0.025-inch guide wire, but these were also unsuccessful. 'Subsequently, contrast was injected, and the pancreatogram showed significant dilation and irregularity of the pancreatic duct in the head, body, and tail, with two filling defects being noted in the pancreatic duct, in the head, proximal to the dilatation, and at the level of the wire retention, consistent with stones. ' The stones were then thought to be completely obstructing and advancing the wires beyond the stones was not thought to be possible. 'At this point, the scope was withdrawn and the procedure was completed. 'In terms of impressions, the impression was a normal papilla and inability to deeply cannulate the pancreatic duct as the wire was recurrently retained in the pancreatic duct. ' in the head secondary to the obstructing PD stones and cannot be advanced more distally. 'The pancreaticogram showed a dilated irregular pancreatic duct with two filling defects at the level of wire retention in the pancreatic head. 'It's recommended.

The procedure is an ERCP with a stent patient. 'The indication is for a 75-year-old female, here for an ERCP for the evaluation of recurrent acute pancreatitis, therapy of pancreatic coagulogenostomy strictures, history of HNPCC, colon cancer treated with partial colectomy, duodenal cancer treated with Whipple's, ' and complicated by recurrent pancreatitis in PD stones presenting with recurrent acute on chronic pancreatitis. 'MRCP performed for evaluation demonstrated dilatation of the main pancreatic duct to 7 mm with an adjacent 1 cm hypo-enhancing lesion near the pancreatic genostomy. ' After the risks, benefits, and alternatives of the procedure were thoroughly explained, informed consent was verified, confirmed, and timeout was successfully executed by the treatment team. 'With the patient in left semipermanent position, medications were administered intravenously. 'The Olympus PCF H190DL pediatric colonoscope was passed from the mouth into the esophagus and further advanced from the esophagus into the stomach. 'And from the stomach, the scope was directed to the mid-jejunum. ' That pediatric colonoscopy was advanced to the stomach, where there was evidence of prior ripple surgery with a gastro-ogigenostomy. 'The afferent limb was at the 9 o'clock position and was intubated for a short distance and appeared normal. 'The afferent limb was across along the lower thoracic aperture, 1 o'clock position, best seen in retroflexion. 'This limb was intubated until a blind end was reached. 'Approximately five folds distal to the end of the limb, there was a hepatic oogigenostomy, which appeared widely patent. ' At the inferior end of the blind limb, there was a severely narrowed pancreatic ojigenostomy. 'The pancreatic ojigenostomy was cannulated with an autotome RX44 cannula preloaded with a ' 0.025 inch angled tip guide wire cannulation of the pancreatic duct to the mid body was achieved but the wire was not able to pass further due to coiling in the side branches. 'This was improved by switching to a 0.025 inch straight guide wire and the wire was coiled in the distal body. 'A pancreaticogram demonstrated dilatation of the main pancreatic duct to approximately 6 mm with an irregular contour and without intraductal strictures or feeling defects. 'White pertinacious debris was noted to spontaneously extrude from the duct with contrast after pancreaticogram. ' To dilate the pancreatic ojigenostomy structure and promote drainage, a straight 7 French and 7 cm plastic pancreatic duct stent was inserted into the duct across the anastomosis and deployed. 'Contrast clearance at the end of the procedure was excellent and the scope was completely withdrawn from the patient and the procedure was completed. 'In terms of impression, there was a history of Whipple's disease. 'The afferent limb was along the lesser curvature in a 1 o'clock position, best seen in retroflexion. 'Severe structure at the pancreatic ojigenostomy. 'The PJ was within ' two centimeters from the end of the PB, the pancreatic ovulatory limb. 'Difficult cannulation of the pancreatic duct because of the strivia stricture. 'The strivia stricture was dilated as sphincterotome and treated with placement of a seven French and seven plastic pancreatic duct stent.

This is test 14. 'We have 57-year-old male with a history of pancreatic head lipoepithelial cyst status post pylorus preserving whipple on July 10, 2013. ' patient is in left semi-prone position now I'm starting the procedure I'm introducing the diurnoscope through the mouth and advancing carefully through the esophagus moving on to the stomach and now into the proximal jejunum limited views of the esophagus and stomach shows no abnormalities I see the previously placed PG stent ' and it's in good position a scout film of the abdomen is performed the pg stent is then removed using a raptor grasping device next i'm advancing a sphincter term pre-loaded with a visiglide to guide wire through the pg track into the pancreatic duct deep cannulation of the pancreatogastrostomy is achieved ' Contrast is injected but initially there is no flow into the jejunum. 'Contrast shows consistent with a tight PJ structure. 'After multiple attempts, the guide wire is successfully advanced into the jejunum. ' However, a dilating balloon and Sohendra dilator could not initially be passed across the PJ structure. 'Using a Sohendra stent retriever, I gently rotate through the structure and after careful maneuvering, the instrument successfully crosses into the jejunum. ' Contrast jejunum now shows free flow into the jejunal limb, confirming successful passage. 'At this stage, a 7 French by 12 cm pancreatic stent is placed from the stomach, transversing the pancreatogastrostomy and PGA anastomosis, extending into the jejunum. ' The stent is noted to be in excellent position with good drainage. 'Now the scope is then carefully withdrawn from the patient. 'Scope is out. 'The procedure is completed. 'There is minimal blood loss, no specimens removed and no immediate complications. 'End of test 14.

This procedure is an ERCP with sphincterotomy, cannulation of papula, and removal of calculus. 'The indication is a 50-year-old female here for an ERCP with right upper quadrant abdominal pain. 'Abdominal outpatient labs were presented to the hospital for further assessment. 'This found out CVD stones likely secondary to coli local lupiasis and MRI-MRCP showed minimal intrahepatic bile duct dilatation. 'CVD 7 to 8 millimeters at least. We have a 31 year old male here for an ERCP for treatment of his bile duct stones. 'The patient has a history of prior suspected gallstone pancreatitis and now he presented with sudden onset severe epigastric pain and we found elevated LFTs and jaundice. It features an ERCP with stent placement, cannulation of the papula and sphincterotomy, and balloon dilatation. 'It's using a Tecolympus EGF-Q190V duodenoscope. 'The... 'Now we're exchanging the guide wire for a 0.25-inch curved-tip guide wire, which is being then advanced to the bile duct selectively. 'A blurry sphincterotomy was performed with the traction sphincterotome using a 30 millimeter cutting wire and a blended electrocautery. 'The sphincterotome was then exchanged out. 'Therefore, a 10 mm into 60 mm fully covered self-expanding metal stint ' was then placed over the guide rail across the papilla. 'There was dilution of the bleeding with stent in situ, excellent contrast drainage and wild drainage from stent at the end of the case. 'The scope was then completely withdrawn from the patient and the procedure was then completed. 'There was minimal blood loss, no specimens, no immediate complications.
